gmmaker > gameWorld

gameWorld 

interface gameWorld

Summary

Properties from gameWorld

boolean
disableDeathBarrier

When set to true, the barrier that kills players when they go offscreen is disabled.

getDiscRadius gmm.d.ts:1604 
getDiscRadius(id: number) → {number}

Get the radius of a disc (affected by balance).

If given the ID of a disc that doesn't exist, it will return 1, as that's the size value of a disc with 0% balance.

It's recommended to only call this function once and store the value somewhere if you use it a lot in your code.

Parameters:
Name Type Description
id number

The ID of the disc.
Returns:
Type Description
number
killDisc gmm.d.ts:1616 
killDisc(id: number, allowRespawn: boolean) → {}

Kill a specified disc.

The disc gets killed in the next step, so it will still exist until you move on to the next step.

It's also not possible to kill a disc while the game is frozen (at the start of a round).

Parameters:
Name Type Description
id number

The ID of the disc to kill.
allowRespawn boolean

When set to true, the disc can respawn (on maps that have "respawn on death" activated). When set to false, the disc can't respawn even if "respawn on death" is activated, like when someone claims a capzone. True by default.
rayCast gmm.d.ts:1645 
rayCast(origin: vector2d, end: vector2d, filter: (hit: rayCastResult) => boolean) → {rayCastResult | null}

Cast a ray from an origin point in the world to an end point.

The filter function's job is to indicate where the ray should stop and return the results. When the ray hits something, the filter function is given details about the hit, and it must judge these details and return true if the hit is valid and the raycast should stop, or false if the hit is invalid and the raycast should keep going.

When the filter returns true, the raycast stops and returns the same info that was given to the filter. If the ray reaches the end position without the filter ever returning true, meaning that there's nothing left to hit, the raycast stops anyways and returns null.

Note: the fixtureId and isCapzone properties in the hit results are only for type body hits, and therefore are undefined in type disc and type arrow hits.

Parameters:
Name Type Description
origin vector2d

The start point of the ray, as a 2d vector, represented by a number array [x,y]
end vector2d

The end point of the ray, as a 2d vector, represented by a number array [x,y]
filter (hit: rayCastResult) => boolean

Filter function that dictates at which point the ray should stop.
Returns:
Type Description
rayCastResult | null
rayCastAll gmm.d.ts:1665 
rayCastAll(origin: vector2d, end: vector2d, filter: (hit: rayCastResult) => boolean) → {rayCastResult[]}

It's like a raycast, but it allows you to find multiple objects in the line.

When the filter returns true, the raycast doesn't stop, instead, it adds the hit info to an array that gets returned once the raycast gets to the end point.

Parameters:
Name Type Description
origin vector2d

The start point of the ray, as a 2d vector, represented by a number array [x,y]
end vector2d

The end point of the ray, as a 2d vector, represented by a number array [x,y]
filter (hit: rayCastResult) => boolean

Filter function that dictates what hits should be ignored and which shouldn't.
Returns:
Type Description
rayCastResult[]
